Comment: Many Asian women did indeed provide “comfort” services to the Japanese Imperial Forces during World War II, but I do not believe they did it at the point of a gun nor was it sexual slavery.    Throughout history, military forces have had no problem finding “comfort women” regardless of the country in which they operated and they were able to find them without kidnapping, coercion or threats of any kind.  Wars create horrible conditions which cause people to resort to often unthinkable means to survive.  For many women, it was the use of their bodies, and there usually was more supply than demand.  I personally witness this during the Korean War and during two years in Vietnam.  Some members of the Imperial Japanese forces no doubt forced women to have sex, which, of course, is rape, but I believe the “comfort women” who served the Imperial Japanese forces in brothels that sprung up and operated near Japanese bases did so voluntarily for pay.

Comment: The names of everyone charged with a crime is public.  That doesn't mean that every name is published in the media. Comment: Not to be too anal, but you mean VPSO (Village Public Safety Officer), not VSPO. And I believe Wassillie, the victim, was a VPO (Village Police Officer), not a VPSO. There is a big difference. A VPSO goes through state training & is recognized & supervised & paid by the state. There are way more VPOs than VPSOs. VPOs get a lot less training, & none of it is from the state that I know of. VPOs get lower pay, & VPOs are not officially recognized by the state due to the state's  opposition to tribal sovereignty. VPOs are paid & supervised by tribal councils. VPOs have high turnover & are often very young guys. VPSOs are meant to be a career option & have longer term professionals, generally. Both jobs are very tough & involve putting yourself in danger without a gun. High stress & low pay. Lots of alcohol-fueled domestic disputes, sometimes relatives.

Water is sacred. Obama stop this!

Comment: By the time I was three, my seven-year-old sister routinely had responsibility to walk her three younger siblings (I was the youngest) about a mile from our swim lessons at the local high school to the movie theater in our little downtown (town was about the population of Springfield). There were many other unaccompanied children of similar ages in line with us. That was just considered normal back then. We would also stop off at parks on the three mile walk home.

What has it come to that children cannot be left playing in a park? Are we legally obligated to stand over them at all times until they get to high school? How sad.

That said, I won't leave my young grandchildren unattended anywhere at any time, ever. However, I only have responsibility for them for fifteen hours per week, so it's not exactly a full-time gig like parenting.

Comment: Motley: You're likely right.  We will spend hundreds of billions attempting to "defend" these low lying areas with dikes, dams, chewing gum or whatever is available.  That decision regarding "uninhabitable" will ultimately be made by the rising sea.  It's not going to be pretty..

For ten years we owned a cabin in a low lying (flood plain) area near the mouth of one of our beautiful Oregon rivers.  The cabin was built on "pilings" to get it above the hundred year flood plain level.  Then one year we had high tides, lots of rain and a storm surge.  For the first time in anyone's memory, the water was below our deck.  We didn't get flooded, but we got the "message."  We sold the cabin.  I fear more and more "ocean front" properties will change status and be "ocean" properties. 

 Some will accuse me of "the sky is falling" talk.  That's OK, ....I take global warming very seriously and feel it's going to increasingly impact our lives.  and, not for the better.  regards, Gary

Comment: Larry, you make a point but miss another.

I long ago abandoned my Sabbath School teacher role. I wasn't asked to leave but by asking questions that made the class uncomfortable, I discovered that I was unnerving folks who had come to be calmed. It just didn't feel right.

The point of this forum, I think, is not confrontation but exploration.

What works for me may not work for you but if I make my point persuasively, maybe it will stimulate thinking, if not in you, maybe others with similar thoughts and questions.

A careful questioning of my conclusions, without a personal attack or an assumption of my ignorance, might, possibly, create thinking in me that leaves me wiser if not more certain.

Certainty and disdain do not lead, in my experience, to much of anything but smoke and no fire.

But I could be wrong. :)

Nothing was done about it, despite years of tongue-wagging and head-shaking, until he finally destroyed a police cruiser by wrapping it around a tree after passing out drunk at the wheel. Was he stripped of his commission and charged? Was he jailed? Was he even disciplined or fired? No; he was moved to another detachment on the other side of the country.

This was forty-five years ago, folks: It was bad then, and it's bad now. The writer is correct. Until (unless?) the protect-our-own mentality of policing changes, you're just going to keep seeing stories like this. The only difference now is that you're seeing more of them.

Comment: Actually the average price for Shale production in the U.S. tends to be closer to $60-$65/bbl.  Yes there are some rich exceptions - Eagle Ford, Marcellus, etc. Companies are willing to drill at $50 though because even though they are taking an accounting loss at $50 they need positive cashflow to service debt; also, most of the cost is upfront so if production has already began it is a sunk cost.   The other big reason is the future market is in a sharp contagion meaning the futures curve is sufficiently steep that producers can afford to sell production forward and then finance the costs of production using those contracts and store the oil until delivery date.

Comment: "(A)ll votes are already counted equally." Well, that is just not true. If it were true, Hillary Clinton would now be president. If it were true, Al Gore would have been president, and there would have been no Iraq War.

A single vote in Wyoming counts the same as three votes in California.

Beyond that, the electoral college, an anachronism dating to the founding of our constitutional government, was designed to give Southern states parity in Congress by allowing non-voting, non-citizen black slaves to be counted as 3/5ths of a landed white man in calculating representation. In other words, it was designed to empower certain states while relatively disempowering other states, and that's what the EC remains today. So in the matter of electing a president, it is states that have representation rather than people. 

We do not have "one person, one vote" in choosing the president, far from it. In the last election, three million voters had their ballots tossed in the trash can.

Comment: "In the past, we did not have the number of extremely hot days..."

You didn't grow up in the Okanagan Valley in the late 50s and early 60s. I did. Loved being outside, running around until about 10:30 in the morning, after that, inside...no air conditioning, but wooden shake roofing did the job until about 3:30 or so, then outside again until our favourite TV shows (like Zorro) came on...then outside again after dinner until dark (about 9 pm) 

And NO air conditioning in classrooms either--not even in the "new" Vernon Jr. High, so immediately before and after summmer holidays, whew. Pretty sleepy in the afternoons...or was that just the effect Mr. Martin had on our English classes?

Thanks for the chance to reminisce.

Comment: The change in vote share might be somewhat interesting for numbers wonks, but the only by-election that has much meaning is the Markham-Thornhill one.

The two Calgary seats are all but guaranteed to vote Conservative while the Ottawa Vanier and Saint-Laurent ridings have voted Liberal for about a millennia.  I would expect the incumbent parties in those 4 seats will do somewhat worse since they are all swapping out high-profile candidates for much lower profile candidates, but I doubt they'll come anywhere close to going to a different party.

Markham-Thornhill though, that is a true "swing" riding.  It is smack dab in the middle of suburban Ontario and is the sort of bell-weather riding.  The party that does well in this kind of riding is likely the one that will win in a general election.

Comment: "a minor $1 billion deficit in 2015-16 was caused by Liberal tax cuts and extra spending"
============

Actually it was ALL spending.

Looking at the 2015/16 budget, the last one written while Harper was PM, vs. the 2015/16 final audited results shows two interesting points:

1. Income tax revenue was significantly higher than budgeted at $192.8B vs. $186.4B

2. Direct program spending was significantly higher than budgeted at $87.2B vs. $81.8B.

So without the big increase in spending that happened after the 2015 budget was finalized the Federal government actually would have had a pretty healthy surplus.  Instead we ended up with a $1B deficit.  While that is a trivially small deficit and essentially "balanced" by any reasonable measure, it is still on the wrong side of 0.

Comment: Immigration? You don't seem to know Canadian history. Canada is defined by accommodation to non-established religion. See the Quebec Act of 1774. Indeed, the American rebels thought it promoted Papism. And our immigration policy thereafter tended to favour WASPs, although Irish Catholics were tolerated. Still, the Colonial government tried to exclude Muslims, Jews, Hindus, and Confucianists. This wasn't necessarily because of religion, but more likely the colour of their skin. Nevertheless, after WWII, accommodation became the norm. I don't see a quarrel about religion here, but a political dispute over the disputed border of Jammu & Kashmir which has dragged on for a century. It is facile to say "Why can't we all just get along" as if the matter is trivial. It's not. Our Charter of Rights and Freedoms protects all religions and therefore we cannot suppress one to please another.

Comment: All of the article's arguments are solid, and, unintentionally, prove why Netflix should _not_ have been exempted from collecting GST. The main points of the article are that Netflix, being a global player bent on success, will only produce Canadian content that will succeed. Indeed they will, I agree. But they will do that regardless of whether or not they are exempted from the GST.

Indeed, if they were subjected to Canada's normal regulations for broadcasters, they would have to invest in Canadian content anyways [analysts' figures vary on this, but the point stands]. In all cases, with or without GST exemption, Netflix would have behaved as this article states -- their drive for success will have them produce high-quality, profitable content.

Exempting them from GST is unnecessary, unfair to competitors, sets a dangerous precedent, and -- worst of all -- places a private corporation's priorities ahead of Canadian social and cultural priorities.

Comment: Actually, O'bonobo, you're a little off here.  And I speak as someone who has hunted all his life, but also as a biologist.  Predators, i.e. those which kill for food, don't target the biggest, strongest animals.  The energy required for, say a lion pride to bring down the biggest buffalo in the herd is excessive in terms of the energy the pride would derive from the meat of their kill.  To say nothing of the increased risk of injury or death attacking the biggest bull.  That's why they go after the small, weak ones.  And that's why herds of prey animals keep the small weak ones in the middle surrounded by the big strong ones.  Even the dinosaurs did that.  So your 'big trophy moose' doesn't have much to do with your dietary requirements.  Only those of your ego.  But I understand that probably needs considerable 'stroking', seeing as to how almost no one takes you seriously.  Just wash your hands afterwards.

Comment: TFSAs are an excellent tool for saving and the best deal out there. But, keep in mind the Bank of Canada altered the bail-in legislation a few years ago. This means if you save beyond what is covered by the deposit insurance, then that money is at risk of bank bail-in in a crisis. Another risk is where banks will freeze your savings as an asset in a crisis. You can look at your digital account and see the numbers, but you will not be allowed to touch. 

With this in mind, spread your wealth over various tax-free or tax sheltered investments in order to skim under the radar of any future bank bail-ins.

Comment: I'm well aware of the history. I lived through it. You're citing a given procedure, not the philosophy underlying the system. That Constitutional allocation was created at a given point in time based on the circumstances at that time, it is not immutable holy writ from on high.

The resources of the State, and the proceeds therefrom, belong to the individual citizens of the state. That at one point we designated, via Constitutional process, part of those proceeds to be -used- by state government (which we -also- designated to operate in a certain manner of our choosing via our amendable state Constitution and which can -also- be changed within the limitations of the Fed Constitution) in a given manner doesn't change that fact.

It still isn't "the state's money," it's ours. It is important to restate the fundamental philosophical and Constitutional premises underlying our system of government lest people start thinking the state owns and controls them, instead of the correct inverse.

Comment: Alpha huh. Not if you're investing in mutual funds (or hedge funds for that matter). Don't confuse Mr. Hallam's performance against his colleagues with that of mutual funds vs.index linked ETFs. His case here is about what happens in the real world, no mutual fund could or would replicate the portfolios of John Heinzl, Norm Rothery or Chris Umiatowski which were all designed for the individual investor, not institutions. There's a mountain of academic as well as industry research that confirms the fact that actively managed funds will virtually always under-perform their benchmark indices over any significant period of time and chasing past performance usually has the opposite effect. A fraction of managers will outperform their benchmarks over shorter time frames, say up to 5 years, but they always regress toward the mean eventually. Even if they could perform for longer periods, identifying those funds ahead of time is unlikely and the odds are stacked heavily against you doing so.

Comment: Mark, you raise an important point about affordability. I'll get to that in a second. First though, there is a big distinction between intercity high-speed rail (HSR) and intrAcity grade-separated rail. Honolulu is not building HSR, they are building a grade-separated metro rail system. Think of it as a subway but elevated. The advantage of these systems over at-grade light rail are that 1) they travel faster between stations (up to 55mph) since there are no traffic lights, cars, bikes or peds to avoid, 2) they can have longer trains (at-grade trains are restricted by the minimum city block lengths), and 3) they can operate with shorter headways (more frequent).  These advantages add up to roughly double the average speed (30 vs 15mph) and around 4 times the maximum operating capacity (ppl/hr/direction).  HSR is a totally different beast. It goes over 200mph and stations are often hundreds of miles apart.

Comment: There's the America they teach in high school, and the America people find out about in the workforce, in the military, on the streets---Why are they so different?  

Because it's still about the powerful over the powerless:  Rights are not gifts; they have to be worked for, fought for, to be maintained over time.  We're not going to absorb them through our TVs---No billionaire is going to give them to us.  They have to be asserted through direct action, or they're going to go away.

The right to a fair wage, to equitable access to health care and the law---The rights of working people to enjoy the benefits of our society:  Free speech, freedom of religion, the right to assemble, to petition our government for redress, to be secure in our persons regardless of race, to arm ourselves in our own defense and the defense of our land; and yes, the right to an equitable vote that is equal to every other American.  One person one vote.

Comment: Planners in jurisdictions around the world have already figured out that there is no possible way to build enough capacity to match the demand for road space. Every increase in capacity is instantly filled by drivers choosing to get into (or back into) cars. 

The only way to keep up with demand is to get people out of single-occupancy vehicles and into car pools, transit, onto their feet and riding bikes. 

Vancouver is even more hamstrung by this reality thanks to the defeat of the downtown parkway project. Increasing downtown access would require huge expropriations and the extra capacity would be filled instantly by commuters getting back into their cars. 

This is what data, logic and research says.

Comment: I differ with Sandia, in that I think where money sits actrually matters - in an RRSP, I don't expect to see the money for decades and invest accordingly.  Guess where my Magna investment sits?  :facepalm:

To topic, the TFSA is money short-term, designed to allow withdrawal and recontribution.  So only pretty liquid issues (high daily volume).

Personally I  treat my TFSA as an "eyes and ears" account - with an outlook a year or two out in my local economy.  I want to be able to walk into the places I invest[ed] in - Canadian Tire, RBC, Tim Horton's (when it was THI), Metro, Sobey's, Apple, and get a feel for how the business is doing and what they offer. My REITs own office towers I walk through all the time.

As a vancouverite shut out of the real estate madness, you might also look at investing in REITs - they are taxed at 0 in a TFSA, pay dividends with nice reinvestment plans. Start with names you see around town at good locations.


Comment: Once again we have an airline disaster story short on facts. 
I would guess there's confusion between "paid for a seat" ie ticket  and "paid for a seat assignment" as in seat fee. 
Assuming the 18 yr old was booked on the flight and a seat fee was paid.
But he traveled on a different flight and we assume paid the necessary fees to change flights.
That's fine.
But when you do switch flights by your own choice the seat fee you pay is non refundable. 
The seat fee is only valid for that person on that flight in that seat.
That original seat may now be empty - assuming Delta didn't resell it- but you have no right to use it. 
Most major airlines have this policy and it's usually clearly spelled out.

Comment: What Would A “Post-Public” Universe Of Schooling Look Like?

There is a growing interest in alternatives to the current schooling system in BC. 

Here are some of the many choices already existing in other jurisdictions or here in BC. 

- Tutoring — already a thriving business in BC, augmenting basic academic skills

- Home education, and online learning — already a practice by many families

-  Private, independent, faith-based schools — already well established

-  Charter schools — a big item in Alberta’s school system

- Education Savings Accounts — a growing field in the United States whereby parents get a sum (usually 90% of public school equivalent) placed into an account to spend on schools, programs and services, etc. from approved resources —a great benefit to parents with special needs students.

- Tuition Tax Credits and other voucher schemes are other practices that enable families to choose what they see as in the best interests of their children.

Comment: This is a pretty normal thing to do.  A visa is the "permission slip" that the country you are visiting gives you so that you can stay in that country for a while.  Just because the US allows somebody to go to college in the US does not mean that person has any claim to live her forever.  
We were on vacation in Nicaragua.  We met some Americans who spend a lot of time there.  They told us the following story: Nicaragua gives you a tourist visa for 3 months.  Every 3 months you have to leave the country and then get another visa.  The government does occasional sweeps of where gringos hang out, places like San Juan del Sur.  (Think: House Hunters International on TV) There is a fine for overstaying your visa and it goes up exponentially and is really high if you are months too long in the country.  If they catch you overstaying your visa, you had better get out your credit card!  Or they put you in jail.
Is Nicaragua racist or xenophobic? Don't most countries do this?

Comment: One commenter says: "...U.S. mainstream media (MSM), are in the process of financial freefall. The reason being, their overly biased news coverage against Trump in the end established a new meme called Fake News."

I don't buy it.  The "freefall" of ad revenue (which, mainly follows declining viewership and readership) started long before Trump was a political candidate. Newspapers have been printing "Fake news" for close to two centuries. It's NOT the shift to on-line readership, either.  Not long ago, G&M  discovered 40 per cent of the [on-line] paper was read by fewer than 1,000 people. For more credible reasons for the decline, read Mass Disruption by former G&M Editor-in-Chief John Stackhouse.  

My take?  News is no longer "scarce"--it's everywhere, anytime. Old photos show people clustered around a radio or the TVs in store windows (just 3 major US networks!); people lined up for the latest "extra."  Today: too many players. Result: most aren't profitable, even on-line.

Comment: With the Arctic, you've got currents that are light and variable circulating below the ice. In the Southern Ocean, you have the powerful Antarctic Circumpolar Current - the world's largest and strongest current - which is both large in volume and highly turbulent on the surface, bashing the sea ice from below. So I'm not surprised that the greater sea ice loss is in the Antarctic.
If you want to know how much water the ACC has, take every single freshwater river in the world, put them all together, and multiply that total volume by 150. That's the water volume of the ACC.
What really makes it turbulent is the fact that Antarctica is the only place in the world where water can move around largely unimpeded. The lack of land masses in the current's path also leave a lot of uninterrupted distance where the wind can blow, further increasing the wave height and current speed.
With both areas of sea ice being of critical importance for the wildlife, this melt is worrying.

Comment: Excellent article.  Only one thing that needs tweaking. But the call for an "R" rating is mere cover for the real result.

"PG" movies bring in all that family cash that "R" movies do not.  By forcing an "R" rating on what would, but for smoking, be a "PG" movie, Glantz hopes to financially coerce the Motion Picture Assoc. into choosing dropping smoking scenes altogether instead of moving to an "R" rating.

Glantz said this himself:  "An adult content or "R" rating for smoking in movies would not have much effect on the movies that children see because, unlike sex and violence, smoking in movies does not sell more tickets  Studios would simply stop putting smoking in movies aimed at an adolescent market."  --  Smoking in Movies: a major problem and a real solution. Commentary, The Lancet.  June 10, 2003.

Comment: Democracies are hopeless at dealing with small groups of disruptive / criminal individuals. Instead they pass laws that restrict the rights of everyone. It is one of democracy's weaknesses. 
The editorial completely ignores the elephant in the room, which is that the usual profile pattern of terrorists is well-known. I sympathize with those who are in this group, but profiling is not new. When Cubans highjacked planes in the 1960s Cubans were targeted for security checks. When the IRA was active, young Irish travelers were searched.  The Nexus system is a roundabout way of negative profiling, essentially eliminating groups who are low risk, but time, effort, and funds are again wasted on a group that is low risk.  
We need more pragmatism here. As the rights of the traveling public are increasingly restricted, criticism of mass, unfocused security searches will increase.

Comment: Ms Holman is quite right.  Commissioners, like all residents of Lane County, are free to support or oppose any initiatives which have reached the ballot.  However, Commissioners Bozievich, Stewart and Leiken's proposal to subject Lane County voter initiatives to Board review and Board authority to either approve or deny an initiative's presentation on the ballot, is an egregiously undemocratic measure.  

The initiative specifically provides citizens the ability to place a measure on the ballot WITHOUT the legislative body's permission or approval.  That is the underlying purpose of the process.  It is a protect against an overbearing, overcontrolling government.  These Commissioners would remove that protection and grant themselves a "preemptive veto" over the initiative process.  

Their proposal is a terrible, anti-democratic measure which must be stopped.  We can, and often will, disagree on specific initiatives; but, I hope we all agree on the importance of the initiative process.

Comment: I think it is a stretch to say half of Americans do not earn enough money to pay income taxes.

There are folks who should pay no income taxes.

But currently you have folks who are wearing $50 - $60K not paying taxes.  Should they pay a lot of taxes? Absolutely not.  Should they pay something?  Absolutely yes.

The point being, you can't have a system that expects a single group to pay and pay and pay and pay.  It is not sustainable.  The system needs to be one where each person pays based on his ability to pay.  Those who earn more should pay more, but not those who earn more should pay it all.

As for the hedge fund manager, I can't really say.  But I will say that the current system of earned income versus dividend income has been at the heart of taxation since Disraeli was PM in the UK.  The idea is to incentive people to save.   

And yes, there are exceptions like hedge fund managers, but this really is an inconsequential minority.

Comment: Jang, in answer:

No, wrong, you do not understand the history, and the columnist has done a disservice by not explaining the history.

Contrary to your historical claim, employer-linked plans emphatically were NOT the USA's "version for providing for their citizens".

No, those employer-based plans were merely the way that companies, wanting to hire workers, were able to entice workers to THEIR factory instead of to the competing factory on the other side of town.    

It had NOTHING to do with America aiming to develop a system to provide for its citizens. What it actually had to do with was worker-hungry industries trying to get around new US government laws that, due to the massive efflux of workers needed for World War II efforts, had FORBIDDEN private companies from offering PAY bonuses or MONEY incentives to attract new workers. 

You cannot understand the US system without understanding its roots: Importantly, it was NOT born out of an interest to provide for society!

Comment: Now that's an idiotic & ignorant remark if I've ever read one! "Just stop smoking. I didn't need the patch or anything". Simply because the "cold turkey" approach worked for you doesn't mean that it'll work for everyone! Your sweeping "analysis" doesn't account for a myriad other critical considerations: how long the individual has smoked, the number of cigarettes that person has typically consumed in a given day over that period, the actual strength/nicotine level of the favoured cigarette brand, the rate at which each cigarette is consumed, full or partial consumption, the conditions/settings where the smoking typically takes place (socially or universally, post-meals, with meals, with alcohol, with coffee,  post-sexual activity, etc.), filtered vs plain cigarettes, the reason the individual started smoking & continues to do so (peer pressure, social rebellion, stress relief) & the subjective length & severity of withdrawl symptoms.

In other words, your claims are baseless & facile!

Comment: An idiotic comment. We cannot boost any economy with waste and environmental destruction. Comment: Injury is the pivot point. Team sports such as football, basketball, hockey have player unions that actively promote "owner accountability" for injury with just compensation when players are forced to retire due to injuries.  This pressure has led sports franchise owners to technologies which enable monitoring of motion and contact for best training practice and real-time risk evaluation, which is linked to insurance sharing this data. Best practices will attract lower premiums, higher risk methods will incur higher premiums.

Individual sports will follow the same regime.  Lower ranked players will risk injury more. As rank rises, insurance penalties and health/injury penalties will become more compelling disincentives.    Lastly, promoters will likely share liability for injuries to their tournament entrants.   For tennis, Turingsense.com is the point on the spear.  Top players have a pretty good idea how many swings they have in their career. Why wouldn't they use them wisely ?

Comment: No. you are wrong. The legislation was passed in 1961 to assist Alberta. The Alberta price of oil was $3.00 while the Saudis delivered up the new St Lawrence Seaway to Chicago for $1.70, occasionally $1.50. The Americans lost interest in Alberta oil. (Sound familiar?) 

Two new pipelines were built to supply Canada as far east as Toronto and Montreal. One carried Alberta natural gas (north of Lake Superior) and the other (Enbridge, south of Lake Superior) carries crude oil. All of Canada west of the Ottawa river which includes Ontario were obligated to use Alberta petroleum.

The Arab oil cartel artificially inflated the price of crude in the mid 70s, eventually to $30 from $3, and a world recession ensued. The substitute for the NOP, the new NEP, was intended to partially shield Canadians from the artificially inflated Arab cartel price.  Alberta felt it was it's right to have the cartel equivalent from Canadians, and so today Ontario buys oil on the world market (St Lawrence Seaway).

Comment: I am not an expert, but have read quite a bit about Alzheimer's disease research and treatment and I think it is accurate to say that there is no drug that "slows the progression of the disease".  The drugs prescribed today treat symptoms and have a positive impact on quality of life but researchers still do not know what causes Alzheimer's disease, so there really is no cure.  There are a lot of theories and there is a lot of research happening but there is really no happy ending for those experiencing cognitive decline due to Alzheimers' and related dementias right now.  Early diagnosis is important because sometimes the symptoms are related to a treatable condition.

Comment: Sure.  There are a couple of things going on here.  First, a lot of work goes into the budget bills.  If the council were to vote a final draft down, it would revert back to the original budget prepared by the mayor.  This is the main reason the budget bills usually pass as amended. 

Another thing is that the bills are long.  They go through five readings, during which time cuts and additions are made.  Each line that is changed is included in the back of the bill, and unless one is pretty familiar with the process or the media or a particular group calls out a specific change, most people will not know that it's there.  That's why I say it would be less transparent than just a single bill like 42.

Bill 42 currently has a lot of attention on it.  If it has to go through to a final vote, people will be able to see who voted yes to support using RPT to fund rail.

Does that help?

Comment: Here's how it's gonna happen.  Most of the older high rise condos in the greater Waikiki, Ala Wai and Ala Moana area are basically a 50-50 or even a 60-40 split between  resident owners and absentee owners who rent their units out.  The absentee owner/landlord could really care less about the cost of installing a sprinkler system.  They would just bump the rents to pay it off.  Residents, usually retired people on fixed income, don't have that luxury.  They'd have to pay it out of their savings and don't have to opportunity to get it back.  You're gonna get a lot of pushback from resident owners.  Absentee landlords are gonna be under pressure to sprinkler up otherwise they're gonna lose business.  But they can't force the resident owners to spend any money on this.  Solution....make the absentee landlords foot the whole bill and sprinkler up their whole complex on their dime.  If they don't, they'll lose business.

Comment: What is more likely to happen is an intensification of what is already happening, i.e. a huge divide between Montreal and the rest of the province.

Montreal attracts the mass of immigrants and refugees, who either already speak English or are highly motivated to learn it. This creates an English-speaking environment in Montreal that does not exist outside it, so people in Montreal can pretty much live in English if they want to,  and everyone needs to be bilingual to get a good job, and it is easy to pick up.

Meanwhile, the rest of Quebec continues and will continue being francophone, with some people being minimally bilingual.

This is the same divide you see in other non-English speaking countries, where people with an incentive to do so are fluent in English, the others not so much.

Comment: This is a fabulous article regarding the Oregon Strawberry dilemma.  They are delicate, delicious, and seasonal.  When the Hoods come one, I go out to the farms and pick up a half-flat, which is just about all I want to deal with for the next few hours.  I slice the Hoods, and add a little sugar to macerate the berries.  I like to freeze them in 6 ounce freezer containers, so that I can reach in often and select the best berries for a dish of ice cream or yogurt.  I do not buy California strawberries.  I have, but the regret comes with the first taste.  I repeat the process of going to the farm enough times to have Oregon berries once or twice a week for the year.  The brilliant red berries look fabulous on some Tillamook Greek yogurt in February.  And they taste like summer!

Comment: Several years ago i was on a flight to DC.  The plane had  3 seats across on each side and the seat between my window seat and the aisle seat was empty.  I wasnt paying too much attention when this young lady sat down in the aisle seat. I kept to my own business and then noticed a small stuffed animal seat belted in between us so i assume she had a small child with her.  The plane rolled to the runway and still no child.  Puzzled, i looked at the lady, then down at the animal.  She was holding the stuffed animal's paw.   She nervously looked at me and said "he is with me...i am afraid of flying".

People used to have blankets and stuffed animals and they seemed to work for them. ..why so many snowflakes now?

Comment: I understand both sides of the issue.  The problem is not an on/off switch.

I was born and raised in Canada, but worked abroad for 10 years.  While overseas, I married and had two children.  I then returned to Canada with my family, and have lived her for nearly 10 years.  So my kids have spent more than half their life in Canada, and have always considered themselves Canadian, even when we lived abroad.  Should they choose to work abroad, however, any children born to them there would not be eligible for Canadian citizenship, even if--like me--they return to Canada and live here for many years.

Why not implement some sort of residency test, as is done with the Old Age Security pension, where entitlement is based on actual residency within Canada?  Why discriminate between those who are sent abroad for work, and those who choose to go abroad for work, but return?

Comment: Josh O’Kane touches on a unique factor that will complicate & lengthen these negotiations; tweets in the night.

The complication in earlier years was that the Senate would try to extract further concessions after a draft treaty was concluded by the Executive Branch. This complication has been removed by the recent practice of the Executive Branch obtaining Senate commitment before negotiations formally begin that a resulting draft treaty will be voted on without amendment.

Now, however, we face the prospect that Trump will personally insert new issues, up-end positions agreed to by his own negotiators, etc. at any stage or at the conclusion of a draft agreement.  There is no constraint on such egocentric interventions.

Lengthy and turbulent negotiations will cast a long shadow over the Canadian economy.

Comment: Let's put it this way, your chances of the fire station being empty is by far greater than you will wait longer than 20 seconds to talk to a 911 dispatcher.   

And FWIW your are correct that the response time clock for first responders begins ticking when the call is answered.

911 call handling and dispatch is tracked differently.

I think NAFPA says medical and fire calls are to be dispatched within 60 seconds of picking up the phone 90 percent of the time.  This is a lot quicker than having just a 60 second average. 

Then a tougher time standard kicks in,, first responders are supposed to be enroute within 6o seconds of the alarm activating.  Fire misses this standard a bit,, AMR which tends to have crews standing-by in their rigs, is in compliance.

AMR gets fined not being in compliance,,,nothing happens to Fire.
I'm not sure at this moment 

BOEC also has goals for emergency police call handling, but I will abstain from any further remarks about these til I confirm those goals.

Comment: Good heavens, there is NOTHING wrong with "On the Origin of Species," IMHO! And as it happens, my favorite sciences are evolutionary biology and vertebrate paleontology, I was once briefly a "fossil explainer" at the evolution-based halls of VP at the American Museum of Natural History, and before that one of my great delights in life was to read  Stephen Jay Gould's column in Natural History mag. 

I know Johnson's book, and think she does a great job guiding people with traditional theological backgrounds to appreciate how Darwin's work improves our thinking about God and God's creation.

My objection is based on Marilynne Robinson's disappointment with the moral coldness, apparent embrace of death, and crushing of independent mental activity that she observes Darwin to have inspired in the scientific mainstream. See "The Death of Adam" and "The Givenness of Things."

Comment: BCE's takeover of Manitoba Tel. now leaves Saskatchewan very isolated in that it will be stuck with  government-owned Sasktel, which neither BCE nor Telus would likely be interested in buying in the foreseeable future, should the provincial government ever want to unload its ownership stake. Both of those companies are now saddled with huge debts. So, Saskatchewan's government will have almost no choice about holding on to Sasktel for years to come, unless it were willing to sell it off at a bargain basement price. That's likely a moot point right now, but it will mean that Sask. residents will be have to put up with an inherently less efficient, government-owned phone service than they could have with either Telus or BCE.
